title: Bobby Ferguson (footballer, born 1938)
text:
Robert Burnitt Ferguson (8 January 1938 – 28 March 2018) was an English professional <a href="association%20football">football</a> player and manager. He was best known for his spell at <a href="Ipswich%20Town%20F.C.">Ipswich Town</a>, as a coach and then manager, from 1970 to 1987. While at Ipswich, he was reserve team coach and first team coach in <a href="Bobby%20Robson">Bobby Robson</a>'s <a href="FA%20Cup">FA Cup</a> and <a href="UEFA%20Cup">UEFA Cup</a>-winning teams, and was appointed manager after Robson's exit.
Playing career.
Born in <a href="Dudley%2C%20North%20Tyneside">Dudley, Northumberland</a>, Ferguson's father <a href="Robert%20Ferguson%20%28footballer%2C%20born%201908%29">Robert</a> and uncle <a href="Ted%20Ferguson">Ted</a> were both professional footballers. Having represented England at schoolboy level, he began his career with <a href="Newcastle%20United%20F.C.">Newcastle United</a> as a <a href="Defender%20%28association%20football%29">left back</a>. He made only eleven league appearances over seven years as he was unable to displace <a href="Alf%20McMichael">Alf McMichael</a> from the first-team.
He later played for <a href="Derby%20County%20F.C.">Derby County</a> before joining <a href="Cardiff%20City%20F.C.">Cardiff City</a> on 31 December 1965 for a fee of £5,000. With Cardiff, he reached the semi-finals of the <a href="1967%E2%80%9368%20European%20Cup%20Winners%27%20Cup">1967–68 European Cup Winners' Cup</a> and made over 100 appearances in all competitions before losing his place in the side to <a href="Gary%20Bell%20%28footballer%29">Gary Bell</a>. He joined <a href="Barry%20Town%20United%20F.C.">Barry Town</a> in January 1969 as player-manager. However, six months later he returned to the <a href="Football%20League">Football League</a> in the same role at <a href="Newport%20County%20A.F.C.">Newport County</a>, signing for a fee of £250. Replacing <a href="Leslie%20Graham%20%28footballer%29">Leslie Graham</a>, he became the youngest manager in the Football League at the age of 31 but finished 21st in the <a href="Football%20League%20Fourth%20Division">Fourth Division</a> in his first season. The club won re-election to stay in the Football League but a 6–1 defeat to <a href="Barnet%20F.C.">Barnet</a> in the <a href="FA%20Cup">FA Cup</a> in November 1970 resulted in his dismissal.
Coaching career.
Ferguson was appointed by fellow northeasterner <a href="Bobby%20Robson">Bobby Robson</a> into the coaching staff at <a href="Ipswich%20Town%20F.C.">Ipswich Town</a> in 1970. He was coach of the Ipswich team than won the <a href="FA%20Youth%20Cup">FA Youth Cup</a> in 1973 and 1975, and as the reserve team coach he developed several young players including <a href="Terry%20Butcher">Terry Butcher</a> and <a href="George%20Burley">George Burley</a>. While reserve team coach, he rejected the offer to manage <a href="Millwall%20F.C.">Millwall</a>. After Ipswich won the <a href="1978%20FA%20Cup%20Final">1978 FA Cup Final</a>, he replaced <a href="Cyril%20Lea">Cyril Lea</a> as the first team coach, and the team went on to win the <a href="1981%20UEFA%20Cup%20Final">1981 UEFA Cup Final</a>.
In 1982, Robson left Ipswich to become <a href="England%20national%20football%20team%20manager">England national football team manager</a>, and Ferguson was named the new Ipswich manager. His tenure was marked by financial constraints due to the construction of the Pioneer Stand at the team's <a href="Portman%20Road">Portman Road</a> stadium. After several near misses, the club were relegated in 1986, and Ferguson was given an ultimatum that he would be dismissed if Ipswich were not promoted immediately back; they lost 2–1 on aggregate to <a href="Charlton%20Athletic%20F.C.">Charlton Athletic</a> in the <a href="1987%20Football%20League%20play-offs">1987 play-off semi-finals</a>. Ferguson became the first Ipswich manager to be sacked.
After leaving Ipswich, Ferguson travelled to Kuwait to work as a coach for <a href="Al-Arabi%20SC%20%28Kuwait%29">Al-Arabi SC</a>, managed by the Scotsman <a href="Dave%20Mackay">Dave Mackay</a>. On returning to England, he had the same role for his former player Butcher's <a href="Sunderland%20A.F.C.">Sunderland</a> and Mackay's <a href="Birmingham%20City%20F.C.">Birmingham City</a>.
Later life and death.
Ferguson settled in Ipswich. He spent his later life watching Ipswich Town and races at <a href="Newmarket%20Racecourse">Newmarket Racecourse</a>, as well as playing golf. He and his wife Ann had a son and a daughter.
Ferguson died on 28 March 2018, at the age of 80. Ipswich announced that they plan to hold a minute's silence and wear black armbands at their next home match, against Millwall on 2 April 2018.
